term.title: Exponential Operation (e^(...))
term.description: The exponential operation raises Euler's number e to the power of the complex expression (iπ). This demonstrates the profound connection between exponential functions and trigonometry through Euler's formula.

term.title: Euler's Number (e)
term.description: Euler's number e ≈ 2.71828... is a mathematical constant that is the base of natural logarithms. It appears naturally in many areas of mathematics, especially in calculus and complex analysis.

term.title: Imaginary Unit (i)
term.description: The imaginary unit i is defined as the square root of -1. It's the fundamental building block of complex numbers and enables us to extend real number arithmetic into the complex plane.

term.title: Pi (π)
term.description: Pi (π) ≈ 3.14159... is the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter. In Euler's identity, π represents exactly half a revolution around the unit circle in the complex plane.

term.title: Addition (+)
term.description: The addition operation combines the result of e^(iπ) with 1. Since e^(iπ) = -1, we have -1 + 1 = 0.

term.title: The Number One (1)
term.description: The multiplicative identity. In this context, it represents unity and completeness in the mathematical universe.

term.title: Equality (=)
term.description: The equality sign shows that both sides of the equation have the same value, demonstrating the beautiful relationship between these fundamental constants.

term.title: Zero (0)
term.description: Zero is the additive identity and represents nothingness or the absence of quantity. It's remarkable that the complex expression e^(iπ) + 1 simplifies to this fundamental number.

equation.title: Normal Distribution
equation.subtitle: "The bell curve that governs natural phenomena"

term.title: Function f(x)
term.description: The probability density function that gives the probability of the random variable x taking a specific value.

term.title: Variable x
term.description: The random variable for which we want to find the probability density.

term.title: Equality (=)
term.description: Shows that the function f(x) equals the expression on the right side.

term.title: Normalization Factor
term.description: This fraction ensures that the total area under the curve equals 1, making it a proper probability distribution.

term.title: Numerator (1)
term.description: The constant numerator in the normalization factor.

term.title: Standard Deviation (σ)
term.description: A measure of the spread of the distribution. Larger σ means more spread out data.

term.title: Square Root (√)
term.description: The square root operation applied to 2π.

term.title: Two (2)
term.description: The constant 2 under the square root, part of the normalization factor.

term.title: Pi (π)
term.description: The mathematical constant π ≈ 3.14159, appearing in the normalization factor.

term.title: Exponential Function
term.description: The exponential function e raised to a negative power, creating the bell-shaped curve.

term.title: Euler's Number (e)
term.description: The base of the natural logarithm, e ≈ 2.71828.

term.title: Negative Sign (−)
term.description: Makes the exponent negative, ensuring the function decreases as we move away from the mean.

term.title: Exponent Fraction
term.description: This fraction in the exponent determines how quickly the probability decreases as x moves away from the mean μ.

term.title: Variable x (in exponent)
term.description: The same variable x, appearing in the exponent to measure distance from the mean.

term.title: Subtraction (−)
term.description: Subtracts the mean μ from x to center the distribution.

term.title: Mean (μ)
term.description: The mean or average value of the distribution, determining where the bell curve is centered.

term.title: Exponent (2)
term.description: The power of 2 in the numerator, making it a squared term.

term.title: Denominator (2)
term.description: The constant 2 in the denominator of the exponent fraction.

term.title: Standard Deviation (σ)
term.description: The same standard deviation σ, appearing squared in the denominator.

term.title: Exponent (2)
term.description: The power of 2 applied to σ, making it σ².

equation.title: Gamma Function
equation.subtitle: "The extension of factorial to real numbers"

term.title: Gamma Function (Γ)
term.description: The gamma function, denoted by the Greek letter Γ (gamma), extends the factorial function to real and complex numbers.

term.title: Complex Variable (z)
term.description: The input to the gamma function, which can be any complex number with positive real part.

term.title: Equality (=)
term.description: Shows that Γ(z) equals the integral expression on the right.

term.title: Definite Integral
term.description: An integral from 0 to infinity that defines the gamma function.

term.title: Integral Symbol (∫)
term.description: The symbol representing integration, a fundamental operation in calculus.

term.title: Lower Limit (0)
term.description: The lower bound of integration, starting from zero.

term.title: Upper Limit (∞)
term.description: The upper bound of integration, extending to positive infinity.

term.title: Power Function t^(z-1)
term.description: The first part of the integrand, where t is raised to the power (z-1).

term.title: Integration Variable (t)
term.description: The variable of integration, representing the dummy variable over which we integrate.

term.title: Exponent z
term.description: The same complex variable z appearing in the exponent.

term.title: Subtraction (−)
term.description: Subtracts 1 from z in the exponent, giving us z-1.

term.title: One (1)
term.description: The constant 1 being subtracted from z.

term.title: Exponential Function
term.description: The exponential function e^(-t), which ensures convergence of the integral.

term.title: Euler's Number (e)
term.description: The base of the natural logarithm, e ≈ 2.71828.

term.title: Negative Sign (−)
term.description: Makes the exponent negative, ensuring the exponential function decays as t increases.

term.title: Variable t (in exponent)
term.description: The integration variable t appearing in the exponential decay term.

term.title: Differential (dt)
term.description: The differential element, indicating integration with respect to t.

term.title: Beta Function (B)
term.description: The beta function, a special function that is closely related to the gamma function and appears in many areas of mathematics.

term.title: Parameter x
term.description: The first parameter of the beta function, typically a positive real number.

term.title: Comma (,)
term.description: Separates the two parameters of the beta function.

term.title: Parameter y
term.description: The second parameter of the beta function, typically a positive real number.

term.title: Equality (=)
term.description: Shows that B(x,y) equals the integral expression on the right.

term.title: Definite Integral
term.description: An integral from 0 to 1 that defines the beta function.

term.title: Integral Symbol (∫)
term.description: The symbol representing integration.

term.title: Lower Limit (0)
term.description: The lower bound of integration, starting from zero.

term.title: Upper Limit (1)
term.description: The upper bound of integration, ending at one.

term.title: Power Function t^(x-1)
term.description: The first part of the integrand, where t is raised to the power (x-1).

term.title: Integration Variable (t)
term.description: The variable of integration, ranging from 0 to 1.

term.title: Exponent x
term.description: The parameter x appearing in the exponent.

term.title: Subtraction (−)
term.description: Subtracts 1 from x in the first exponent.

term.title: One (1)
term.description: The constant 1 being subtracted from x.

term.title: Complement Term (1-t)^(y-1)
term.description: The second part of the integrand, representing the complement (1-t) raised to the power (y-1).

term.title: Left Parenthesis (
term.description: Opens the complement expression (1-t).

term.title: One (1)
term.description: The constant 1 in the complement term.

term.title: Subtraction (−)
term.description: Subtracts t from 1 to form the complement.

term.title: Variable t
term.description: The integration variable t in the complement term.

term.title: Right Parenthesis )
term.description: Closes the complement expression (1-t).

term.title: Exponent y
term.description: The parameter y appearing in the exponent of the complement term.

term.title: Subtraction (−)
term.description: Subtracts 1 from y in the second exponent.

term.title: One (1)
term.description: The constant 1 being subtracted from y.

term.title: Differential (dt)
term.description: The differential element, indicating integration with respect to t.

term.title: Einstein Tensor (G_μν)
term.description: The Einstein tensor describes the curvature of spacetime. It's constructed from the Ricci tensor and scalar curvature, encoding how spacetime is curved.

term.title: Einstein Tensor Symbol (G)
term.description: The letter G represents the Einstein tensor, named after Albert Einstein.

term.title: Index μ (mu)
term.description: The first spacetime index, which can take values 0, 1, 2, 3 corresponding to time and three spatial dimensions.

term.title: Index ν (nu)
term.description: The second spacetime index, which can take values 0, 1, 2, 3 corresponding to time and three spatial dimensions.

term.title: Addition (+)
term.description: Adds the cosmological term to the Einstein tensor.

term.title: Cosmological Constant (Λ)
term.description: The cosmological constant, representing the energy density of empty space. Einstein originally introduced it to allow for a static universe.

term.title: Metric Tensor (g_μν)
term.description: The metric tensor describes the geometry of spacetime, determining distances and angles in curved spacetime.

term.title: Metric Symbol (g)
term.description: The letter g represents the metric tensor, which encodes the geometry of spacetime.

term.title: Index μ (mu)
term.description: The same spacetime index μ appearing in the metric tensor.

term.title: Index ν (nu)
term.description: The same spacetime index ν appearing in the metric tensor.

term.title: Equality (=)
term.description: Shows that the left side (geometry) equals the right side (matter-energy content).

term.title: Einstein's Gravitational Constant
term.description: This fraction represents Einstein's gravitational constant, relating the strength of gravity to the curvature of spacetime.

term.title: Eight (8)
term.description: The numerical factor 8 in Einstein's gravitational constant.

term.title: Pi (π)
term.description: The mathematical constant π appearing in the gravitational coupling constant.

term.title: Newton's Gravitational Constant (G)
term.description: Newton's gravitational constant, the fundamental constant that determines the strength of gravitational attraction.

term.title: Speed of Light to Fourth Power (c⁴)
term.description: The speed of light raised to the fourth power, appearing in the denominator of the coupling constant.

term.title: Speed of Light (c)
term.description: The speed of light in vacuum, a fundamental constant of nature.

term.title: Four (4)
term.description: The exponent 4, indicating that c is raised to the fourth power.

term.title: Stress-Energy Tensor (T_μν)
term.description: The stress-energy tensor describes the density and flux of energy and momentum in spacetime.

term.title: Stress-Energy Symbol (T)
term.description: The letter T represents the stress-energy tensor, describing matter and energy content.

term.title: Index μ (mu)
term.description: The same spacetime index μ appearing in the stress-energy tensor.

term.title: Index ν (nu)
term.description: The same spacetime index ν appearing in the stress-energy tensor.
